Graphical abstract The effect of oxygen pretreatment on HCHO catalytic oxidation of Ag/MCM-41 catalysts has been investigated from 500°C to 800°C in this paper. The highest HCHO surface reaction activity is achieved on the silver sample pretreated at 700°C. The state and the dispersion of silver species on the support are strongly related to the pretreatment temperature. The increase of the O2 pretreatment temperature for Ag/MCM-41 catalysts results in the diffusion of Ag2O clusters from outside to inside of the channels. And the amount of Ag2O clusters inside the channels becomes maximum at 600°C. Interestingly, it is found that the smaller metallic Ag nanoparticles coexist with large particles when the catalyst is pretreated at 700°C. It is suggested that Ag2O clusters inside of MCM-41 pores improves the HCHO adsorption capacity and accelerates the formation of HCHO adsorption intermediates, particularly dioxymethylene(DOM) ad-species. And the formed meallic silver particles with smaller size at 700°C plays an essential effect on the formation of formate intermediate and the enhancement of surface reaction activity. It is also concluded that CO2 formation rate from formate is higher than that from DOM species in HCHO oxidation. The decrease of HCHO surface reaction activity after oxygen pretreatment at 800°C may be due to the decrease of the Ag2O clusters inside MCM-41 pores and the aggregation of metallic Ag nanoparticles. Keywords Ag/MCM-41 HCHO O2 pretreatment Particle size Ag2O 1 Introduction Silver has been widely used in the catalytic oxidation reactions with outstanding activity, such as ethylene epoxidation [1–3], hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehydes [4,5], partial oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde [6,7], oxidative coupling of methane to ethane and ethylene [8–10], selective catalytic reduction of NO x [11–13], VOCs catalytic oxidation [14,15] and CO oxidation [16–18], and so on. It is generally accepted that the catalytic activity of Ag depends to a large extent on the size of the Ag particles, the nature of the active sites, which are proved to be of fundamental importance [17,19]. Moreover, different pretreatment atmosphere and temperature not only leads to the geometric structure changes, such as the particle size, the morphology, but also results in the electronic structure changes, for example, surface chemical states, redox properties and so on then affects the catalytic reaction acitivity [18,20,21]. Many researchers have supposed that treating silver catalysts in an oxygen atmosphere may result in different surface structures, comparing with the treatment in vacuum or inert gas [18,22]. Bron et al. [23] suggested that morphological changes and surface restructuring of the Ag nanoparticles occurred during O2 pretreatment, which might modify the catalytic properties of acrolein hydrogenation in Ag/SiO2 catalysts. Shimizu et al. [24] suggested that silica-supported silver nanoparticles with the surface oxygen atoms due to O2 pretreatment acted as an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the alkylation of arens with alcohols and styrenes. Beneficial effects of oxygen pretreatment of Ag/SiO2 catalysts in the acrolein hydrogenation have been demonstrated by Bron et al. [23]. Gac et al. [25] reported that the catalytic activity of Ag catalyst was strongly related to the pretreatment atmosphere and the dispersion of crystallites or the formation of strong silver-oxygen bounding. Therefore, these Ag–O interaction due to the high-temperature O2 pretreatment has proved the outstanding activity for many reactions. Our previous studies [22,26] have also reported that pretreatment in oxygen at 500°C can markedly improve the activity of Ag/SiO2 catalysts for the low temperature CO oxidation. The oxygen pretreatment at 500°C redisperses and restructures the metallic Ag particles on the surface, and more interestingly, the subsurface oxygen species formed during the pretreatment can not only stabilize the active Ag structures but also participate in the CO oxidation. Su et al. [27] have also proved that silver catalysts undergo massive structural change during oxygen pretreatment at high temperatures (>500°C). In Ag/SBA-15 catalysts, we found that O2 pretreatment at 900°C could induce the evaporated silver atoms to be redeposited on the support, and meanwhile diffuse into the channels of SBA-15, forming more highly dispersed small metallic silver particles inside the channels [18]. Therefore, the active species inside or outside mesoporous materials play the different role in the catalytic oxidation activity. It has been known that the formation and oxidation of different adsorption intermediates, such as dioxymethylene (DOM), formate, and adsorbed CO, strongly affect the reaction rates in HCHO catalytic oxidation reaction on Ag/MCM-41 catalysts [28,29]. It is reasonable to suggest that, according to the previous reported results, the intermediates formation will be directly related with the different silver states and their dispersion on the support. The investigation about the state and dispersion of silver species and the relationship of silver state with the formation of intermediates and HCHO oxidation activity is rare. Then it is essential to discuss the state of silver species on MCM-41 in HCHO catalytic oxidation reaction because it is very important for the investigation of the reaction mechanism and the activity improvement of silver catalytst. Herein, the influence of oxygen pretreatment temperature in the silver structure and the HCHO catalytic activity of Ag/MCM-41 catalysts was systematically investigated and discussed. In situ FTIR, temperature programmed desorption (TPD) and temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) were all used to study the characteristics of HCHO adsorption and reaction on the Ag/MCM-41 catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Commercial porous materials (MCM-41) were used as the supports. To endow the catalytic activity, 8wt.% silver was introduced into the support using nitrate precursor of silver by incipient-wetness impregnation method. The obtained wet samples were dried at room temperature overnight and then at 100°C overnight. The catalysts were sieved into 20–40mesh granules and then pretreated with O2 atmospheres at different temperatures (500–800°C) before testing and characterization. And the O500, O600, O700, and O800 stands for the Ag/MCM-41 catalysts pretreated with oxygen at 500, 600, 700, and 800°C, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Specific areas were computed from these isotherms by applying the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method in Quantachrom NOVA4200e. Before measurement, the samples were treated by degassing at 300°C for 4h. The pore diameter distributions were calculated from desorption branches using the BJH (Barrett–Joyner–Halenda) methods. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements of the catalysts were carried out on a Rigaku D/max-γb (λ =0.1542nm) and operating at 40kV and 200mA. The patterns were taken over the 2θ range from 10° to 80° and a position-sensitive detector using a step size of 0.02°. Transmission electron microscopy (Tecnai G2 Spirit) operated at 120kV was used to study the morphology and the particle size of catalyst samples. The sample was supported on a copper mesh for the TEM analysis. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded in air on a SHIMADZU UV-2450 UV–vis spectrophotometer. Reference spectra were collected with pressed BaSO4 disks. The following parameters were used to collect data: 5.0 spectra band width, 0.5nm data pitch, 800–190nm measurement range, and 200nm/min scanning speed. H2-TPR (temperature programmed reduction) was carried out in Quantachrom Automated Chemisorption Analyzer. 0.1g sample after different pretreatment in fixed bed reactors was then pretreated in He at 200°C for 1h, cooled to room temperature in He in chemisorption analyzer. For H2-TPR study, it was exposed to a flow of 30ml/min H2/Ar (10vol.% H2) mixture. The temperature was programmed with a constant heating rate of 10°C/min. 2.3 In situ FT-IR In situ FT-IR spectra were recorded in BRUKER VERTEX 70 using variable-temperature quartz cells. A catalyst wafer (12mm×0.1mm in size and ca. 30mg in weight) was placed in the flow IR cell-reactor and then pretreated in He flow at 300°C for 40min. All spectra were recorded with a resolution of 4cm−1 and accumulating 16 scans. A background spectrum was subtracted from each spectrum, respectively. 2.4 Adsorption/desorption and surface reaction experiments The adsorption/desorption and surface reaction of HCHO were performed in a fixed catalytic reactor system in the middle of which 0.1g catalyst (20–40 mesh) was packed. The reaction was performed at temperatures ranged from room temperature (RT) to 500°C. A thermocouple was placed in the middle of the catalyst bed for the temperature measurement. Gaseous HCHO was generated by flowing He over trioxymethylene (99.5%, Acros Organics) in an incubator kept in an ice water mixture. A HCHO adsorption breakthrough curve was obtained for each run to ensure the saturation of the catalyst surface using the mass spectrum (Ametek, LC-D200M). The catalysts were purged with high purity helium for 1h to fully remove physically adsorbed HCHO, and then the temperature was ramped at 10°C/min from RT to 500°C. The effluent from quartz reactor was analyzed by MS. The exhaust line from the reactor to the mass spectrometer was maintained at ∼120°C to prevent the condensation of the formaldehyde and reaction products. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of HCHO was carried out in a continuous flow of helium, and the temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) experiments were conducted in flow of O2/Ar (30vol.% O2). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization As we all know, silver will be restricted in the formation of minimum-energy crystal structures during pretreatment. Thus, the silver catalyst will undergo the pronounced geometric and/or electronic structure changes after high-temperature treatments in order to obtain the structure which is most thermodynamically favorable. 3.1.1 Textural properties To measure the effects of O2 pretreatment temperature on the textual properties, the N2 adsorption and distribution of pore diameter curves are presented in Fig. 1 . As shown in Fig. 1(a), these samples exhibit the type IV adsorption/desorption isotherms with H1 type hysteresis loop having inflection around P/P 0 =0.3–0.45, which are typical characteristics of mesoporous materials according to the IUPAC classification [28]. The inflection around P/P 0 =0.3–0.45 region indicates the uniformity of the narrow pore size distribution of these samples [29]. As shown in Fig. 1(a), the hysteresis loops get smaller (P/P 0 =0.3–0.45) and the unclosed hysteresis loops at P/P 0 >0.6 become obvious when the silver catalyst is pretreated at 700°C and 800°C, indicating the existence of the interparticle pores which is corresponding to capillary condensation in the interparticle pores [30]. This indicates that the original pore structure of MCM-41 is changed and the new interparticle pore is formed after the O2 pretreatment at higher temperatures (>600°C). It has been known that the formation of the interparticle pores on Au/MCM-41 catalyst facilitates the transport of reactant and product molecules, allowing the higher CO conversion [31,32]. The pore size distributions (Fig. 1(b)) are calculated from the desorption branch of the isotherm using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. It can be obviously observed that the average pore size is centered on 2–3nm in the samples pretreated at 500°C and 600°C. With the increase of the O2 pretreatment temperature, the pore size distribution seems not be concentrated. As shown in Fig. 1(b), the broader pore size distribution has been observed in O700 sample which is consistent with the results of N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms. Table 1 lists the BET surface areas, total pore volume, average pore diameters, and BJH desorption pore diameters. The Ag/MCM-41 samples possess higher surface areas (above 600m2/g) after the O2 treatment below 700°C. However, the surface areas and BJH desorption pore size (mesopore size) of the O700 and O800 samples become smaller than O500 and O600 samples, which should be the shrinkage of the mesopores walls during the high-temperature treatment [33]. In addition, the average pore size shifts into the large size (from 3.61nm in O500 sample to 4.62nm in O800 sample) with the increase of the O2 pretreatment temperature. The obvious double unclosed hysteresis loops and sharp decrease of BET surface area for Ag/MCM-41 after pretreatment at 800°C may be due to the large structure change and/or structure destruction of MCM-41. The effect of support structure on the state of metal or oxide species and catalytic activity will be discussed in the near future. 3.1.2 Wide-angle XRD patterns X-ray diffraction patterns (2θ =10–80°) of the pretreated Ag/MCM-41 catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . For all the samples, a broad peak at about 2θ ≈22.0° is ascribed to the amorphous silica. The peaks around 38.0°, 44.3°, 64.4°, and 77.6°, which are, respectively, corresponding to (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes of the structure of metallic silver, are observed for Ag/MCM-41. No lines due to silver oxides are observed. The silver diffraction peaks become sharper and more obvious with the increase of the pretreatment temperature, and meanwhile the half-width of the Ag (111) peak decreases. The metallic silver particles occur the aggregation to form larger size particles with the incease of the pretreatment temperature, and the size calculation results are presented in the Table 1. 3.1.3 TEM results To clearly elucidate the size and the dispersion of silver particles on the different samples, TEM images are shown in Fig. 3 . It gives the comprehensive information on the geometric structure of Ag particles. As shown in Fig. 3, the silver particles exhibit spherical shape and are dispersed on the surface of the support. Ag particles on O500 sample (Fig. 3a) are mostly around 20nm in size, which is in well accord with the XRD results. With the increase of the O2 pretreatment temperature to 700°C, parts of Ag particles are aggregated (Fig. 3b). However, the homogeneously dispersed smaller Ag nanoparticles (<5nm) are also observed on the O700 sample (Fig. 3c), which are not detected by XRD. That is to say, the larger and smaller metallic Ag nanoparticles coexist in O700 catalyst. The treatment with oxygen at different temperatures results in the obvious change in the silver particle size and the support textural structure, and plays an essential role in the dispersion of silver particles on the support. 3.1.4 UV–vis DRS As we all know, the optical properties of solid materials are closely related to the microstructure, such as electronic state, defect sites, and energy level structure. The diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectroscopy is known to be a very sensitive probe for the identification and characterization of the co-existence of various silver structures. Fig. 4 shows the UV–vis spectra of the silver catalysts pretreated with oxygen at different temperatures. The presence of the broad bands centered at 410nm are the characteristic absorbance of metallic Ag particles with several nanometers or much larger [34]. As shown in Fig. 4, with the increase of the pretreatment temperature, the blue-shift is observed (from 405nm in O500 sample to 387nm in O700 sample), which suggests that the size of silver particles changes in the trend of small size [20]. This result is in excellent agreement with the data obatined from TEM. 3.1.5 H2-TPR results of Ag/MCM-41 samples It is generally accepted that an essential key to investigate the catalytic activity of silver catalyst begins with understanding the interaction of oxygen with silver. H2-TPR is a useful technology to investigate the redox properties and phase composition of the various Ag/MCM-41 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5 , each sample exhibit several hydrogen consumption peaks and the shapes of the peaks differ from each other. The peak at the low temperature (T <200°C), the peak at the middle of temperature (200°C< T <600°C), and the peak at high temperature (T >600°C) are found in H2-TPR profiles on various Ag catalysts. The peak at low temperature (T <200°C, denoted as Peak 1) was attributed to Ag2O clusters that existed outside of MCM-41 pores (below XRD detection limit) [18,35]. The peak at the middle of temperature (200°C< T <600°C, denoted as Peak 2) in the H2-TPR profile can be assigned to larger sized Ag2O clusters that existed inside of MCM-41 channels, whose size is smaller than the Ag2O clusters outside of MCM-41 pores. However, its size is larger than the other kinds of Ag2O clusters inside of MCM-41 channels (T >600°C, denoted as Peak 3) [35]. It is found from Fig. 5 that the reduction Peak 1 at low temperature disappears when the pretreatment temperature increases from 500°C to 600°C. However, the intensity of the reduction Peaks 2 and 3 gets stronger. The oxygen pretreatment at 600°C induces the diffusion of more Ag2O clusters into the channels [18]. The corresponding H2 consumption amount per gram of catalysts is calculated from the H2-TPR results. As shown in Table 2 , the amount of those Ag2O clusters inside of MCM-41pores in O600 sample (25.15μmol/g) are several times as large as the amount of those species in O500 sample (7.1μmol/g), respectively. Then, with the increase of O2 pretreatment temperature to 700°C, slight decrease in amount of H2 reduction Peaks 2 and 3 (20.71μmol/g) compared with the O600 sample (25.15μmol/g) was observed. With the continuous increase of O2 pretreatment temperature to 800°C, the amount of these Ag2O clusters inside of MCM-41 pores sharply decreases (7.39μmol/g). Moreover, the H2 reduction Peaks 2 and 3 shift to the lower temperature when the O2 pretreatment temperature increases to 800°C, which might be ascribed to the broader pore size distribution in O800 sample as shown in the above N2 isotherms results. 3.2 HCHO adsorption performance in different Ag/MCM-41 catalysts by HCHO-TPD and in situ FT-IR experiments The adsorption–desorption process can be studied by temperature programmed desorption (TPD) techniques and in situ FT-IR experiments, which can probe different surface structures by monitoring the desorbed species over the range of temperature [36]. As we all know, the recycle catalytic oxidation process comprises of diffusion, chemical adsorption, surface reaction, desorption, and reverse diffusion steps. The adsorption of the reactant molecules on the active sites, including adsorption capacity and intensity, plays a key role in the activation of reactant molecules, which finally influences the catalytic reaction performance. A good catalyst should express the large adsorption–desorption capacity of the reactant molecules and the appropriate activation temperature to react with other reactants on the surface of catalysts. Therefore, the reactants must be desorbed at moderate reaction temperature range in TPD experiments of reactants. Fig. 6 shows the HCHO-TPD profiles of the Ag catalysts pretreated with O2 at different temperatures. As shown in Fig. 6, the complete HCHO desorption temperature shifts to the lower temperature in all Ag catalysts compared with the pure MCM-41 (181°C→125°C). It indicates the silver addition improves the HCHO desorption behavior at low temperatures. In addition, it is found that the initial and complete HCHO desorption temperature in O700 sample is higher than the catalysts pretreated at 500°C and 600°C, which can assure no desorption of reactants from the surface before catalytic reaction. It is also found that the HCHO adsorption capacity is enhanced in all Ag catalysts comparing with pure MCM-41. With the increase of O2 pretreatment temperature from 500°C to 600°C, the HCHO desorption amount increases a little and the desorption temperature slightly shifts to high temperature (from 127°C to 132°C). Of which, the HCHO desorption amount is obviously enhanced with the increase of pretreatment temperature to 700°C, and meanwhile the desorption temperature also shifts to high temperatures (from 132°C to 150°C). However, both of HCHO desorption amount and desorption temperature decreses with the further increase of O2 pretreatment temperature to 800°C. To well demostrate the adsorption process and detect the intermediates formed on the surface of silver catalysts after HCHO adsorption, the in situ FT-IR experiments were conducted on the different Ag catalysts. Fig. 7 illustrates the FT-IR spectra of all catalysts after they are exposed to a flow of He+HCHO for 60min at room temperature. As shown in Fig. 7, the bands of these intermediates, such as dioxymethylene (DOM) (1285, 1430, and 1470cm−1), formate (2798, 2913, and 2980cm−1), molecular HCHO (1715–1770cm−1), adsorbed CO (203cm−1), and the gas phase CO2 (2330cm−1) [37], are all observed in all Ag/MCM-41 catalysts. However, the intensity of these intermediates is different from each other in these catalysts. With the increase of the O2 pretreatment temperature from 500°C to 600°C, it can be observed that the intensity of DOM and adsorbed CO intermediates is obviously enhanced, however, no obvious change for formate species is found. To the contrary, the intensity of formate species is obviously increased and the intensity of DOM and adsorbed CO shows a little change when the O2 pretreatment temperature increases from 600°C to 700°C. With the continued increase of O2 pretreatment temperature to 800°C, the HCHO adsorption behavior becomes weak, and the intensity of these intermediates such as DOM, adsorbed CO and formate are all decreased. This adsorption behavior is consistent with the above HCHO-TPD results. 3.3 HCHO surface reaction activity (HCHO-TPSR experiments) HCHO-TPSR (temperature programmed surface reaction) experiments were carried out in a continuous flow of O2/Ar (30vol.% O2) atmosphere after the adsorption saturation of HCHO. Analysis of the desorbed species was done by mass spectrometry (MS). The reaction of gas oxygen with adsorbed HCHO was not found in pure MCM-41 sample. The obvious gas oxygen consumption (m/z =32) and large formation of CO2 (m/z =44) and H2O (m/z =18) were observed on all silver catalysts (Fig. 8 ). And the initial temperature of CO2 formation can be used as the reaction activity in this work. The higher CO2 production temperature is, the poorer HCHO surface reaction activity is. It can be seen from Fig. 8 that the surface reaction activity is strongly dependent on the oxygen pretreatment temperature. The initial CO2 production temperature significantly decreases with the pretreatment temperature from 500°C to 700°C. Then O800 sample is deactivated for the HCHO oxidation. 3.4 Discussion In conclusion, O2 pretreatment temperature shows a great influence on the Ag particle size and Ag species state. A possible structure model and the formation of intermediate species in the HCHO adsorption on Ag/MCM-41 catalysts pretreated with oxygen at different temperatures (500–800°C) are proposed (Fig. 9 ). Usually, high temperature treatment of solids can result in the morphological changes, including of surface and bulk transitions, in order to attain a minimization of the total free energy. Surface transitions at the gas–metal interface often significantly occur than bulk transformations at lower temperatures. Bulk transitions typically require temperatures in excess of the Tammann temperature (T Tammann =0.5T M, T M represents the melting point) in order to produce structural changes [38,39]. Ag nanoparticles formed on the surface of support easily become aggregation when the treatment temperature is above Tammann temperature (480°C) [18]. In our work, when the Ag/MCM-41 catalyst is pretreated with oxygen at 500°C, the relatively small metallic Ag particles (Ag particles mean size is 15.1nm calculated from XRD results) are formed outside and inside of the MCM-41 pore. At the same time, the oxygen pretreatment would also result in the formation of Ag oxide species due to the interaction between Ag and O. A few of the large sized Ag2O clusters outside of MCM-41 pores and a small amount of those Ag2O clusters inside of MCM-41 pores are observed. The metallic silver nanoparticles continuously aggregated with the further increase of the O2 pretreatment temperature due to the thermo effect. In O600 sample, the metallic Ag nanoparticles size is obviously increased (19.2nm calculated from XRD results). It should be pointed out that the diffusion of Ag2O clusters from outside to inside of the MCM-41 channels happens, and the size of those Ag2O clusters becomes smaller than the clusters in O500 sample. As shown in Table 2, the amount of those Ag2O clusters inside of MCM-41 pores in O600 sample (25.15μmol/g) are several times as large as the amount of those species in O500 sample (7.1μmol/g). Combining the FTIR and activity results, it indicates that the Ag2O clusters inside of MCM-41 pores improve the HCHO adsorption capacity and accelerate the intermediates formation, particularly DOM ad-species, then finally increase the HCHO surface reaction activity. It is worthy to note that the amount of those Ag2O clusters inside of MCM-41 pores in O700 samples (20.71μmol/g) is slightly reduced compared with O600 sample (25.15μmol/g). Certainly, the amount of DOM formed in HCHO adsorption in O700 sample is also slightly lower than that in O600 sample, however, is still higher than that in O500 sample. Although the aggregation of metallic silver nanoparticles has happened after oxygen pretreatment at high temperatures, however, it is surprising that oxygen pretreatment at 700°C also induces the formation of highly dispersed ultrafine metallic Ag nanoparticles. It has been known that the treatment of silver under oxygen at high temperatures can restructure the silver surface. And the oxygen pretreatment at 900°C could induce the evaporated silver atoms to be redeposited on the support due to the oxygen adsorption on the dangling bonds of the silver atoms, and meanwhile diffuse into the channels of SBA-15, forming more highly dispersed small silver particles inside the channels based on the evaporation–deposition–diffusion mechanism [18]. The formation of larger metallic silver nanoparticles on the support after oxygen pretreatment at 800°C, which may be due to the large structure change and/or structure destruction of MCM-41 at high temperature, induced the decrease of adsorption ability for HCHO and the formation of intermediates. It is generally accepted that the catalytic activity of Ag catalysts depends to a large extent on the size of the Ag particles, and the reaction tends to occur easily on smaller particles [40]. For example, it has been reported that metallic silver nanoparticles with smaller size in SBA-15 obviously enhanced the HCHO adsorption capacity, then strengthen the HCHO adsorption and dissociation performance compared with the larger sized metallic silver particles prepared by the wet impregnation method [19]. In O700 sample, the metallic silver particles with small size improve the chemical adsorption between HCHO and silver active sites, then increase the HCHO desorption amount and HCHO desorption temperature. It should be pointed out that the formate intermediates formation obviously increases in O700 sample even though no obvious change in the amount of Ag2O clusters inside MCM-41 pores comparing with O600 sample is observed. It is reasonably assumed that the existence of the small sized metallic Ag nanoparticles improves the formate intermediates formation in O700 sample. In our previous studies [36,37], the HCHO adsorption and oxidation reaction path was examined in Ag/MCM-41 catalysts. The formed DOM would firstly be dissociated into formate via a Cannizzaro-type mechanism, then oxidized into CO. At last, formate and CO were oxidized into CO2 by heating. And meanwhile the non-active DOM ad-species reacted into molecular HCHO. The formed formate species would also be directly oxidized into CO2. It is indicated that CO2 conversion rate from formate is more important than that from DOM intermediates for HCHO oxidation. Therefore, the best HCHO surface reaction performance in O700 sample (96°C) should be ascribed to a large amount of formate formation due to the existence of highly dispersed ultrafine metallic Ag nanoparticles. As above mentioned, only large metallic Ag particles exist in O800 sample and the size of Ag2O clusters inside MCM-41 pores also become larger as proved in H2-TPR results. Therefore, the DOM formed on Ag2O clusters inside MCM-41 pores and the formate formed on metallic Ag nanoparticles are all reduced in O800 sample. Finally, the HCHO surface reaction activity and the HCHO adsorption capacity all sharply decrease with the further increase of O2 pretreatment temperature from 700°C to 800°C. Thus, O2 pretreatment temperature not only strongly affects the physical structure, such as Ag particle size, but also the Ag states of silver catalysts. The Ag particle size and Ag state strongly influences the formation of HCHO adsorption intermediates, including of DOM and formate species. The formation of Ag2O clusters inside of MCM-41 pores improves the formation of DOM, and the enhancement of formate formation is attributed to the small sized metallic Ag nanoparticles in the Ag/MCM-41 catalysts pretreated with oxygen at different temperatures. And it can be concluded that the CO2 conversion rate from formate is higher than that from DOM species in HCHO oxidation reaction. 4 Conclusions In this study, the effect of O2 pretreatment temperature on HCHO catalytic oxidation of Ag/MCM-41 catalysts was investigated. It was found that O2 pretreatment temperature not only strongly affected the physical structure, such as Ag particle size, but also the Ag states of silver catalysts. The aggregation of Ag metal particles occurred on Ag/MCM-41 with the O2 pretreatment temperature. Interestingly, some smaller sized metallic silver particles formed when the catalyst was pretreated with oxygen at 700°C, and the larger and smaller metallic Ag nanoparticles coexist in O700 catalyst. Meanwhile, it was also found that O2 pretreatment did change the formation of oxidative silver species in Ag/MCM-41 catalysts. With the increase of the O2 pretreatment temperature from 500°C to 600°C, the Ag2O clusters diffused from outside to inside of the channels and the size of those Ag2O clusters inside MCM-41 pores was also decreased. These small sized Ag2O clusters inside of MCM-41 pores improved the HCHO adsorption capacity and accelerated the HCHO adsorption intermediates formation, particularly DOM ad-species, thus increasing the HCHO surface oxidation activity. In O700 sample, the enhancement in HCHO desorption amount and the increase of HCHO desorption temperature window was attributed to the metallic silver particles with small size. Most importantly, the existence of the small sized metallic Ag nanoparticles improved the formation of formate intermediates, and the highest surface reaction activity of HCHO in O700 sample should be ascribed to the higher CO2 conversion rate from formate intermediate. coredata.dc:description: The effect of oxygen pretreatment on HCHO catalytic oxidation of Ag/MCM-41 catalysts has been investigated from 500°C to 800°C in this paper. The highest HCHO surface reaction activity is achieved on the silver sample pretreated at 700°C. The state and the dispersion of silver species on the support are strongly related to the pretreatment temperature. The increase of the O2 pretreatment temperature for Ag/MCM-41 catalysts results in the diffusion of Ag2O clusters from outside to inside of the channels. And the amount of Ag2O clusters inside the channels becomes maximum at 600°C. Interestingly, it is found that the smaller metallic Ag nanoparticles coexist with large particles when the catalyst is pretreated at 700°C. It is suggested that Ag2O clusters inside of MCM-41 pores improves the HCHO adsorption capacity and accelerates the formation of HCHO adsorption intermediates, particularly dioxymethylene(DOM) ad-species. And the formed meallic silver particles with smaller size at 700°C plays an essential effect on the formation of formate intermediate and the enhancement of surface reaction activity. It is also concluded that CO2 formation rate from formate is higher than that from DOM species in HCHO oxidation. The decrease of HCHO surface reaction activity after oxygen pretreatment at 800°C may be due to the decrease of the Ag2O clusters inside MCM-41 pores and the aggregation of metallic Ag nanoparticles.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of oxygen pretreatment on the surface catalytic oxidation of HCHO on Ag/MCM-41 catalysts
